4.author: Philopoemen81
4.body:
Not sure if you’ve worked in the public service - I have - but you’re prohibited from making comment about policy on social media. 

Common sense approach applies - no one will care if it’s just to your friends on your private Facebook page. Conversely, they very much will care when it’s an article from the national broadcaster.

This is why when journalists are directed to speak with the department media section whenever they call for comment, and if you are permitted to make public comment, you are coached, and the content you are providing is reviewed by media section before you make that comment, and if you are misrepresented by the journos, their CoS or editor gets an earful and limited cooperation in the future. 

To be clear, I don’t care that the doctor made his comment, or where he made it - my ire is directed at the journalist behind this story.

6.author: This-Understanding10
6.body:
I urge you to reread my comments - I have never said that people are wrong for thinking that codeine works for them as individuals, nor would I be obstructive if it was requested.   


But yes I have said that codeine is not a good drug despite several anecdotal accounts saying otherwise - but I am looking at the research, which takes hundreds of thousands of accounts over various periods of time. For the vast majority of people, it does more harm than good.   


I've said this term several times in my comments but all opiates when used for a long period of time cause hyperalgesia ie. an increase in the sensation of pain. If I were not to discuss this with patients, I'd be most likely actively hurting them. That is part of the collaboration - being informed about all the current knowledge that is available, especially of the risks.

6.author: artimist101
6.body: This sort of thinking is why people with chronic illness have no faith in the health system any more. You want to look at studies of population groups, look at how well drs are viewed in literally any chronic health forum on the entirety of the internet, yet that data doesn't seem to impact how drs treat their patients somehow.

6.author: This-Understanding10
6.body:
It sounds like you've had some bad experiences, which is unfortunately common in our healthcare system.   


I'm not going to comment on the validity of forums vs scientific papers but if it makes a difference we do actually perform studies on doctor-patient relationships and how best to communicate. This is why Australia is teaching this collaboration method of patient interaction and moved away from a paternal medicine style (ie. "I am the expert and I have last say on what is best for you, and no I will not explain.") It's a slow change, but if you are in the medical field you should be able to see the difference in the different generations of health practitioners and one for the better. Pain medicine is also just a very difficult field - not all pain is associated with damage to the body. If it were I'm sure there would be more options to treat it. But with our current knowledge its often a battle of give and take.   


At this stage, I seem to be a punching bag for some frustrations with the medical system which while valid, is not appropriate to direct my way. Unless you have specific examples that I can learn from (I am autistic, so I do value that opportunity to learn), I think this conversation is done.

6.author: artimist101
6.body:
I do see younger doctors are moving to collaborative care, which is also what I was taught under. But what a lot of dr don't realise, and this is what I mean about the way you come across in replies; telling people that you acknowledge their experience but that "the vast majority" don't agree with them, is, well, paternalistic (among other thing). It seems you obviously don't mean to be, as you're nicer than I should deserve as I have been hostile, but it is. And this is a trap that any highly educated group inevitably falls in unfortunately.

When I read a study or a write up I always look at who didn't follow the norm, and how often that happened. I see so many doctors, not just to myself, but that my patients tell me about, that really don't want to see the experience of people that aren't typical or "expected", even including people having side effects to medications. Which can be dangerous. 

Australia has demonised codeine to the point that I have seen signs in multiple practices saying "we don't prescribe codeine". This is what people around Australia deal with, and it is in part due to this constant speaking about codeine like this and not looking at it with nuisance. I should apologise, as you are coming at this with more thoughtfullness than most, but your voice adds to the overall noise that causes those who don't want to think about it, to put signs up like this across the country, and that then hurts people unnecessarily.

As you have agreed with, codeine can still be used effectively, and I think the national conversation needs to shift towards "effective prescribing" rather than "alternative prescribing", because the latter causes codeine to be excluded and looked down on, rather than seen as a legitimate part of the toolkit. And i guess that is what I've been trying to get across, this negative talk around codeine rather than neutral talk; I feel it is inadvertently harming patients.

6.author: This-Understanding10
6.body:
I had a bit of a think about your comment because I will admit on the first pass, I didn't understand. Now I think I can understand that having your own experience essentially deemed 'weird' and 'not normal' would feel isolating, dismissive and rude. You are a person, not a statistic and no perfect science is going to capture the vast spectrum of human experience. 

When I talk to patients that, as you say, didn't follow the norm, it's going to spark my curiosity and that of many of my colleagues. We have seen a vast spectrum of unusual and finding out why is important. Sometimes it's an old prescription that has mistakenly never been stopped. Sometimes a patient has been on it for so long, it's a remnant of an old practice. Sometimes it's a preference of either doctor or the patient from an experience they had. Other times a patient didn't even know what it was! By asking, I am checking that there is no error, no better option, or just the patient's thoughts. I type all this out because, in truth, the shorthand for this in conversation is often the phrase "oh that's not the vast majority..." with a question at the end, either explicit or implied (or something similar). And that yeah, sounds judgemental.   


However, having experienced the many patients that are on codeine because of any number of the above examples with the knowledge that yes it does do harm to so many people, I do feel it's important to always ask about it. Otherwise, I would potentially do harm. 

In the context of this thread, where there are a lot of people mistakenly stating that it is an excellent drug that was pulled and that there is nothing to cover the gap it leaves I do think it's important to state how ineffective and harmful it can be and that there are alternatives available to explore - and I speak in the general sense because I speak to a general population on a Reddit thread. The knowledge of options gives way to nuance, that can be discussed on the scale of an individual.  And whatever works on an individual level is valid.  


And to state clearly, codeine is not recognized as a good drug due to comparisons of how our other drugs perform -  it has extremely variable absorption, pro-kinetics and effect. For some, it doesn't work at all. For others is equivalent to a small dose of morphine. Combine that with the risk of increasing pain, increasing adverse events and risk of addiction and it makes a poor profile to something like a statin which shows improvement in life expectancy in the value of years or meloxicam which lasts a whole day with consistent pain reduction and little risk. However, it's not bad because it's in the opioid family. It's not bad due to stigma. It is still a valid option.   


That is very a broad summary describing clinical medicine vs public health. I hope that I've captured my intentions in this not being a personal attack, but rather an explanation of why I and other health professionals say the things we say - always with the intention to help rather than harm.   


I do agree that Australia does demonize codeine - in fact medicines, in general, are still viewed in a very negative light - they are chemicals, big pharma trying to hook you into their pocket, they are not natural etc. I've seen and had experiences of people criticising those who choose to take medicine as being weak, or a failure of some kind. And I do recognise coming into a thread that is filled with nay say for something that works for you, after coming from the fight from the outside world would start to get a bit much.   


I'm not quite clear on the terms effective vs alternative prescribing. I believe that the national conversation should include our current knowledge of pain and how big of a role our environments and brain can impact it - the ultimate aim would be to cure chronic pain entirely, and as our understanding of pain continues to grow we move closer to that goal. That being said codeine is a legitimate part of the tool kit, and I don't think I have presented a neutral view of it, I think it can be argued that it is nuanced.   


This is now very long, I apologise. Thank you for engaging with me in a positive way. I hope the rest of your night is restful and that your future interactions with our healthcare system are more positive.

13.author: Lullo420
13.body:
You quote it yourself.  
 
It's discrimination, based on people of a different ethnicity.  
  
People with certain ethnicity, or race, get more representation in government or the constitution than others.

13.author: mrbanvard
13.body:
More representation for one group isn't inherently discrimination though. It's the why of one group getting more representation, and/or the resulting outcomes that make it discrimination, or not.

>Discrimination is the act of making unjustified distinctions between people based on the groups, classes, or other categories to which they belong or are perceived to belong.

*Unjustified* distinctions. So if for example the justification (the 'why') for giving one group something different is to give an equitable outcome, then it's not necessarily discrimination. 

Of course, it could still be, because there's no hard and fast rule of what is unjustified or justified, or what is equitable. 

But in this case, what would you say is unjustified about making this distinction for one group? 

What would be a potential inequitable outcome?

13.author: Lullo420
13.body:
It absolutely is discrimination.  
  
Within a democracy, you cannot just hand out more power to one group, especially a race, and still maintain a fair and equal representation.  
  
Your definition of discrimination is rather cherry picked, as means merely to recognize a difference between one thing and another.  
Regardless, in the your case it is utterly and entirely 'unjustified" to dismantle universal suffrage based on race.  
  
Past atrocities are not a valid reason to unravel democracy. Indigenous people are not the only ones to have suffered atrocities on this planet. No one should be getting more votes or representation based on their race or suffering their ancestors had to live through. Should a German Bavarian get more votes than a Saxon German, because their ancestors suffered more genocide during the Roman invasions or the second world war? Should polish immigrants who were taken for genocide to the gulags get special appointed ministers and should Syrian refugees not get those? Of course not. 
  
We all should get equal representation. That's the very core of democracy.  

  
People who want this ethnicity/race based representation are racists. As they discriminate based on race even by the definitions you use.

13.author: mrbanvard
13.body:
I just used the first line from Wikipedia if you follow the link for discrimination from the wiki racism page.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrimination

That was ideal because it made it clear which discrimination sense was being referred to. I meant to link it though sorry, just to make it clear where I got it from. 


>Within a democracy, you cannot just hand out more power to one group, especially a race, and still maintain a fair and equal representation.

I agree, and if our democracy handed out power equally to all groups we wouldn't be having this debate!

Power not being equal is already a huge issue across many groups, not just race. I certainly think it needs to be a very careful consideration. 

But with this particular case, in what way would one group would end up with more power than another?

What actual outcomes are you suggesting could happen that would be problematic?

17.author: espersooty
17.body:
Yeah, I hope through the advancements with technology we can reduce our Chemical usage as i hate buying it, its very expensive. GMO's are generally never harmful for the environment they only bring advancements as we are able to use specific genes to make the plants more resistant to diseases and pests which cuts down on the overall pesticide and insecticide use. 

I'm quite hopeful for the future of vertical farms replacing the traditional Vegetable growing operations where it is suitable as i know not every type will suitable like Watermelons will be a massive problem to make work in that sort of farm, Leafy veg like spinach lettuce etc can easily be replaced with in door vertical farms and I know this is against the vegan mindset and all but There is also the possibility of adding fish farms along side of the vertical farms to utilize the same system. 

The broadacre grains industry wont ever be replaced in my opinion, it'd just shift and change with the rise of Autonomy and other technology.

17.author: espersooty
17.body:
I don't associate emotions with ideas so I don't know what you be trying say. 

When I am wrong I'd happily admit to being wrong, but I'm not wrong on this topic with all the information and research I have available. 

"*Changes to lifelong habits are very difficult but spitting the dummy and denying reality is stuff kids do.*"

I mean sure? I wasn't "spitting the dummy" I didn't anything you said, I've seen different information that says something completely different to what people in this thread are trying to spread. The people who deny facts are the vegans/animal rights activists who whenever something goes there way they have a sook about it saying its "industry sourced" its "biased" all these things but they when they do the same thing its completely fine. Double standards such a massive achievement.

Sure, I'm happy with that. I'm sick of trying to explain my side and the proper information i see within the Agricultural industry just to be shot down because someone found a "non-biased" paper saying otherwise.

17.author: reyntime
17.body:
Yup, I can definitely see things like robotic farming, more soil and water sensors to only deliver what's needed to plants, etc, and I think that stuff will be beneficial (where it's powered by renewables). 

And of course indoor vertical farming will only make the land use of farming more efficient. 

Pretty sure the majority of the Netherlands' food is now grown indoors, as they have little space for other farming methods.

17.author: reyntime
17.body: You are killing them prematurely to eat them. This is simple fact.

17.author: espersooty
17.body:
"*Yup, I can definitely see things like robotic farming, more soil and water sensors to only deliver what's needed to plants, etc, and I think that stuff will be beneficial (where it's powered by renewables).*"

Yeah we are honestly waiting on Hydrogen to be developed as Electric wont reach the type of capacities and hours we work on average, A lot of farms now are already on Solar for water bores and house electricity etc but there is definitely more and more moving towards it as diesel is just getting massively expensive to run pumps constantly and to run generators. 

"*And of course indoor vertical farming will only make the land use of farming more efficient.*"

Yeah definitely it'd open up more area to go into other types of farming not just strictly Vegetables on the Higher quality soils, you can start branching into Speciality crops with that. 

Yeah i believe you are correct on the Netherlands, it makes sense when you can do it so easily with Vegetables. I don't honestly see the point in having fields upon fields of Lettuce growing when we have Vertical farms, 

I believe the costs are the biggest barrier to the industry right now with a vertical farm costing around 100 million dollars to build at scale once that price sorta comes down it will be more manageable to build and scale up.

19.body: We weren’t Australians until 1901. Why is that so hard for you to understand? In fact we were still British subjects for many years after that.

19.author: Eric_Mudaxe
19.body:
>We weren’t Australians until 1901.

Disagree, 1788 is where history for modern Australians diverged from the history of the British people. Before that point Australians and the British shared a common history. After that point the experiences of British people and Australians was vastly different, and it saw the fomentation of a divergent culture and situational context. 

>we were still British subjects for many years

So what? Most British subjects did not live in Australia. Are you trying to say that the British subjects that didn't live in Australia are as culpable, regarding the colonisation of Australia, as the British subjects that actually colonised Australia and carried out atrocities against the natives? If you want me to debate this then you'll have to explain the relevance of this statement. 

Would it help if we clarified the definition of what is meant by Australian and narrowed it down to Australian British when referring to Australians? By Australian British I would be referring to Australians of British descent who settled in Australia, aka the British people that colonised Australia and whose historical narrative significantly and objectively diverges from the historical narrative and reality of the British people. 

By British I would be referring to the British people who live in the British Isles, the ones who live in their native land. I hope this helps.

23.author: Obur2304

I don’t like house development in photos tho I can understand looking at that and not liking metal roof but.

23.author: scissorsgrinder
23.body: Tiles are way less of a problem than concrete slab roofs  in hot climates, yeah. In Melbourne it is better to have more thermal mass (mostly via walls) because the nights are cool enough compared to day that it can stay cool enough indoors potentially all day, the thermal mass tends to average it, bit like living by the ocean vs inland. In Darwin there is very little contrast in temperatures so you don’t want that delay in heating up and cooling down. (I used to have a job there helping people reduce their energy bills.)  Brisbane may be somewhere in the middle. But black roofs are never a good idea in Australia, or at least most of it..

23.author: scissorsgrinder
23.body:
So colourbond is:  
a) the best thing you can do to your house  
b) just beautiful

Okay sure, but I was asking about insulation and thermal mass in different climates, and criticising the choice of dark rather than light colourbond in terms of cooling efficiency.

23.author: Obur2304
23.body: Colourbond is better we even use better insulation we use Bradford yellow blanket I don’t know the exact name. But tiles only use sarcing which is only a thin layer of Mylar and cardboard no thinker then paper. Plus tiles have gaps by design so water can run through and not spill over the laps but it’s not that air tight so heat would escape easily. Metal isn’t air tight but there’s not gaps and holes like every tile.

24.author: gestaltdude
24.body:
I think it's more about avoiding any legal issues for the department. By stating they can give only general advice (and really mean it :P ) no one can turn around and say they were guaranteed they or a loved one would get a visa. Given how long and complicated the simplest of visa can be these days (A simple tourist visa took a month in 2012), it is probably the only way the department can protect itself against those who record their phone calls, etc.  


In a twist, I briefly saw my wife with a metric crap tonne of paperwork spread around her last night. I'm not sure if this is the continuation of the online process (there seemed to be a LOT of paper), or if the news I'd been able to get the other paperwork signed without her having to take time off had an effect. Time will tell I guess.

When I went to an all boys Catholic school (Marist Brothers) we had biology over a whole year of which human biology and sex was covered fully enough. 56.author: iced_maggot
56.body:
It’s basic economics - If the debt isn’t indexed (I.e. doesn’t rise in-line with inflation) then over time the debt will decrease in real (I.e. inflation adjusted) terms. Think of it this way, say you have a $50k debt in todays money which you never pay off. Well in 30 years due to inflation that $50k only buys you the same amount of goods that $25k would buy today. So by doing nothing your debt is worth less because money today is always worth more than money tomorrow. If you wait long enough your original $50k debt will be worth $5 worth of future goods due to inflation and at that point your original debt is meaningless. 

Have a read of this - the NZ system is incredibly generous because it effectively forgives or writes off student loan debt especially in high inflation environments at taxpayer expense. 

https://www.taxpayers.org.nz/high_inflation_leads_to_637_million_debt_write_off_for_uni_graduates

56.author: MindlessRip5915
56.body: Oh, you’re spinning right wing talking points. Interest lost.

56.author: iced_maggot
56.body:
Right wing talking points!?  Mate I think uni should be free just like the boomers got it. Do you honestly not understand how inflation works or are you just yanking my chain? I really want to give you the benefit of the doubt here and think there’s some miscommunication going on. 

Like seriously, if you don’t understand I would genuinely encourage you to do some reading or even spend a bit of time on r/AusFinance because having a base level of financial literacy on stuff like this is super relevant to your financial well being. 

If through your proposal, the government is going to effectively write off the debt over X due to years anyway, just make it free to being with and greatly expand access to higher education.

56.author: MindlessRip5915
56.body: You invalidate anything you have to say when you refer to … _that_ organisation. The so-called “Taxpayers Union” is New Zealand’s version of the Institute of Public Affairs.

56.author: iced_maggot
56.body:
Oh, okay fair enough then, my bad - I had no idea they were a right wing org. I’m obviously not a Kiwi and had never come across them. Was just looking for something that explained the impact of inflation on debt and that popped up in my Google results with an official sounding name and specifically mentioned NZ student loans. A hopefully more acceptable source via Investopedia to get the general point across:

“When a business borrows money, the cash it receives now will be paid back with cash it earns later. A basic rule of inflation is that it causes the value of a currency to decline over time. In other words, cash now is worth more than cash in the future. **Thus, inflation lets debtors pay lenders back with money worth less than it was when they originally borrowed it.**”

That last sentence is the whole rationale behind indexation so that the debt doesn’t automatically get smaller over time.

https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/111414/does-inflation-favor-lenders-or-borrowers.asp

59.author: Mixz0r
59.body:
No that's OK. I work in the soil testing industry, specifically the civil engineering aspects of soil. The gauge we have (Nuclear Density Meter, or ‘nukes’ as we call them) is used to determine the in-situ density and moisture content of compacted soil in the field. It’s a probe that we put down a small hole in the ground, and the gauge reads the amount of radiation that passes through the soil over a known amount of time (normally 60 seconds) at a know depth (normally 100 – 300mm). 

We wear small devices on our person that absorb radiation and these are tested regularly to ensure we’re not receiving too high a dose. There is legislation in place to ensure correct use, storage and transport of these devices.

  
There are dozens of labs around WA and some of them would have dozens of nukes.

Again, Cheers for getting back to me! Hope you had a good weekend.
